title: Can I write this way: 'I haven't the cell number of doctor'? - Quora

response.answer_text: While “I haven’t the number” isn’t wrong, in conversational English most people would say “I don’t have the number.” You’re speaking about a particular doctor, so you need to say “the doctor.” “I don’t have the cell number for the doctor.”

Can I write this way: "I haven't the cell number of doctor"? People would understand what you meant, but it doesn’t sound natural. I would say, “I don’t have my doctor’s cellphone number”, or, as I’m British, I wouldn’t use the expression ‘cellphone’ at all; I would say, “I don’t have my doctor’s mobile number”.
No. Doctor needs a determiner. And the standard, contemporary was of making have negative is like all other verbs; don’t have. I don’t have the cellphone number of my doctor.
